body_html:
@DEKHTIARJonathan In general we don't make guarantees about static shape inference in your graph. This is because it can become arbitrarily complex, or sometimes impossible. E.g. in your original example, the size is determined by newsize = tf.multiply(input_shape, (2, 2)); in the general case this may be an arbitrary expression.

So I'd consider this normal behavior. BTW using set_shape to explicitly set the shape is a reasonable workaround.

@DEKHTIARJonathan In general we don't make guarantees about static shape inference in your graph.  This is because it can become arbitrarily complex, or sometimes impossible.  E.g. in your original example, the size is determined by newsize = tf.multiply(input_shape, (2, 2)); in the general case this may be an arbitrary expression.
So I'd consider this normal behavior.  BTW using set_shape to explicitly set the shape is a reasonable workaround.
body:
@DEKHTIARJonathan In general we don't make guarantees about static shape inference in your graph.  This is because it can become arbitrarily complex, or sometimes impossible.  E.g. in your original example, the size is determined by `newsize = tf.multiply(input_shape, (2, 2))`; in the general case this may be an arbitrary expression.

So I'd consider this normal behavior.  BTW using set_shape to explicitly set the shape is a reasonable workaround.
